articles.headline: How Joe Manchin Left a Global Tax Deal in Limbo
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen’s signature achievement is in jeopardy if the United States cannot ratify the tax agreement that she brokered.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen’s signature achievement is in jeopardy if the United States cannot ratify the tax agreement that she brokered.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In June, months after reluctantly signing on to a global tax agreement brokered by the United States, Ireland’s finance minister met privately with Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen, seeking reassurances that the Biden administration would hold up its end of the deal.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Word of Trump Media Deal Is Said to Have Leaked Months in Advance
articles.snippet: Federal authorities are investigating a surge in trading that preceded the announcement of a $300 million deal with the former president’s media company.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities are investigating a surge in trading that preceded the announcement of a $300 million deal with the former president’s media company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months before former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company unveiled an agreement to raise hundreds of millions of dollars last fall, word of the deal leaked to an obscure Miami investment firm, whose executives began plotting ways to make money off the imminent transaction, according to people familiar with the discussions.

articles.headline: Democrats Navigate Nuanced Views on Abortion Among Black Voters
articles.snippet: Faced with a streak of conservatism about abortion among some Black Americans, a vital constituency for President Biden, Democrats are framing the issue as part of a broader civil rights struggle.
articles.abstract: Faced with a streak of conservatism about abortion among some Black Americans, a vital constituency for President Biden, Democrats are framing the issue as part of a broader civil rights struggle.
articles.lead_paragraph: As she and other faith leaders sat last month with Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the implications of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade, the Rev. Najuma Smith-Pollard, a pastor at a Black church in Los Angeles, reflected on the complex feelings in her community about abortion.

articles.headline: Extreme Heat Puts Life on Hold in Britain, a Land Not Built for It
articles.snippet: In a country more accustomed to temperate weather, a brutal heat wave tested Britain’s infrastructure and forced millions to choose between a Stygian commute or a stifling home office.
articles.abstract: In a country more accustomed to temperate weather, a brutal heat wave tested Britain’s infrastructure and forced millions to choose between a Stygian commute or a stifling home office.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Trains slowed to a crawl. Schools and doctors’ offices shut their doors. The British Museum closed its galleries. Buckingham Palace curtailed the changing of the guard. And the government urged people to work from home.

articles.headline: ‘My Worldview Has Been Destroyed’: Chinese Banking Scandal Tests Faith in the System
articles.snippet: The disappearance of ordinary savers’ money, and the government’s seemingly indifferent response, could pose a major test for the Communist Party’s legitimacy.
articles.abstract: The disappearance of ordinary savers’ money, and the government’s seemingly indifferent response, could pose a major test for the Communist Party’s legitimacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The saving opportunity with the rural bank in central China looked, to Sun Song, a 26-year-old-businessman, like a great find. It would be linked to his existing account at a large, reputable state-owned bank. The rural bank was also offering high interest rates, making it seem like an ideal place to park his roughly $600,000 in savings.
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang and Zixu Wang

articles.headline: Hey, Is Anybody Watching the Interns?
articles.snippet: School is out for the summer — but in some cases, so are the bosses.
articles.abstract: School is out for the summer — but in some cases, so are the bosses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alex Hyman pictured his summer internship as being one part “Entourage” and one part “The Office”: people screaming into telephones Ari Gold superagent style, others menacing their desk mates as unnervingly as Dwight Schrute did at Dunder Mifflin.
